title: Periodic Phenomena - matching period and graph

content.prompt: If the function h{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"} has a period of 3{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}, which of the following could be a portion of the graph of h{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"} in the xy{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}-plane?

choices.label:
• All coordinates are approximate.
  • The curves appear to be copies of the same shape curve with different transformations.
  • The first curve begins at (negative 6 comma 3), moves up slightly to level off at a maximum point (negative 5 comma 4), then moves down to end at (negative 3 comma 0).
  • The second curve is a copy of the first curve starting at (negative 3 comma 3), with a maximum at (negative 2 comma 4), and ending at the origin.
  • The third curve is a reflection of the second curve over the y axis and begins at the origin, moves up to a maximum at (2 comma 4) and moved down to (3 comma 3).
  • The fourth curve is a reflection of the first curve over the y axis and begins at (3 comma 0), moves up to a maximum at (5 comma 4) and moved down to (6 comma 3).

​

  • All coordinates are approximate.
  • The curves appear to be copies of the same shape curve with different transformations.
  • The first curve begins at (negative 4 comma 0), moves up gradually to level off at a maximum point (negative 2 comma 4), then moves down slightly to end at (negative 1 comma 3).
  • The second curve is a copy of the first curve starting at the origin, with a maximum at (2 comma 4), and ending at (3 comma 3).
  • The third curve is also a copy of the first curve starting at (4 comma 0), with a maximum at (6 comma 4), and ending at (7 comma 3).

​

  • All coordinates are approximate.
  • The curves appear to be copies of the same shape curve with different transformations.
  • The first curve begins at (negative 3 comma 0), moves up gradually to level off at a maximum point (negative 1 comma 4), then moves down slightly to end at (0 comma 3).
  • The second curve is a copy of the first curve starting at the origin, with a maximum at (2 comma 4), and ending at (3 comma 3).
  • The third curve is also a copy of the first curve starting at (3 comma 0), with a maximum at (5 comma 4), and ending at (6 comma 3).

​

  • All coordinates are approximate.
  • There is a single curve that appears to be made of copies of the same shape curve with different transformations. Where one curve ends, the next begins.
  • The first portion of the curve begins at (negative 3 comma negative 3), moves up gradually to level off at a maximum point (negative 1 comma 1), then moves down slightly to end at the origin.
  • The second portion of the curve is a copy of the first portion starting at the origin, with a maximum at (2 comma 4), and ending at (3 comma 3).
  • The third portion of the curve is also a copy of the first portion starting at (3 comma 3), with a maximum at (5 comma 7), and ending at (6 comma 6).

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Construct equivalent graphical, numerical, analytical, and verbal representations of functions that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context, with and without technology.
